attribution: Library and University Collections, The University of Edinburgh

metadata.value: This image depicts an extraordinary instrument apparently designed for use in astronomy. Shaped like a gigantic wheel, it rests on a clawlike stand and revolves on a pivot. The object's use, the image's creator and the date of creation are all unknown.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The album contains images of many people, places and costumes from Van Meer's travels in Northern Europe, including noblemen and nobility.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This finely illuminated fifteenth century Book of Hours contains vibrant images with intricate foliage designs. The book contains eleven images contained in initials portraying scenes from the Bible: this image depicts the Agony in the Garden.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: An impression taken from the seal of Robert Burns (1759-1796). The seal depicts a shield bearing a holly bush below a crossed shepherd's pipe and crook. Above the shield is a wood lark on a branch of a bay tree. The seal was designed by Robert Burns himself and contains the motto 'better a wee bush than nae beild' [better a small bush than no shelter], which references back to Ayrshire and Burn's love of pastoral themes. The impression of Burn's seal in the Laing collection is in red wax, is on paper, and has been mounted for preservation purposes. Burn's seal, cut into glass and hung on a silver chain, is held at the Robert Burns Birthplace Museum in Alloway.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Commision from the Dodge of Venice, Recto
metadata.label: Repro Title

metadata.value: One of the earliest depictions of land wind-surfing, this image shows a 'horseless wagon' transporting the Prince of Orange, thought to be the figure at the back of the vehicle wearing red and gold dress and a military flag, and flying his flag.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. One of over 3,000 charters held in the Laing collection. This charter is described in the Calendar of the Laing Charters as being a "Charter by Sir William Richardson, vicar perpetual of the parish church of St. Cuthbert of Langtoun, with consent of James [Stewart], commendator of Kelso, and John [Philp], abbot of Lindores, administrator of Kelso, granting to WILLIAM COCKBURN of Chowslie and MARGARET GALBRAITH, his spouse, the lands of Gretrig, Vicar's Croft, Hauchis, Langlands and commonflat of said vicarage, in the barony of Langton, Berwickshire, except one croft on the east side of the church called Hoy's Croft, now occupied by Kentigern Home, curate of the church, with pasture for one horse in the said lands: To be held in feu-farm for a yearly feu-duty (old and new) of nine merks 13s. 9d. Dated at Kelso, 30th October 1539. Witnesses, Mr. Patrick Cokburne, rector of Petcokkis, Alexander Gledstanis, rector of Garwod, Richard Richardson, vicar of Sproustoun, Richard Ker, James Lawson of Hundby, Thomas Makdowale of Makcarstoun, Alexander Hoppringill, Sir William Chepman, and Sir Thomas Quhite, chaplains, Sirs Robert Lausoun, Thomas Watho, and John Rolland, notaries. Signed by the commendator, abbot, and the following members of the convent: William Newtone, William Lausoun, Walter Murray, Adam Chatto, Robert Lawsoun, John Paton, James Ancrum, George Gray, Jasper Wynrem, William Wrangham, Thomas Turnet, John Cosar, Thomas Newmouch, Michael Chatto, Thomas Schaw, Alexander Wod, Thomas Symson, and Patrick Ogyll. Thomas Watho, notary, signs for William Richardson. Seal of Richardson (a chevron) and that of the commendator of Kelso still attached". The Kelso seal is attached near the middle of the document and shows the Virgin and child. The seal of Sir William Richardson is attached to the left. A third seal is missing.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: J. Anderson, Calendar of the Laing Charters, A.D. 854-1837, belonging to the University of Edinburgh (1899).

metadata.value: Representation of the House of Lords, showing King James VI & I seated on his throne, holding the golden sceptre and wearing the State Crown. The Queen sits to his left. The picture shows the historical layout of the House of Lords in 1614.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Painted mythical scene depicting Perseus on Pegasus saving Andromeda from Cetus. From the inside cover of an Album Amicorum, a manuscript book in which people recorded names and signatures of people they met, scenes they encountered in travel and mottos. This particular book is described in the Laing handlist as an "Album of Latin Verses, with curious coloured drawings. 17th century".
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The Lady Grange papers include letters that describe, in her own hand, the plight of Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange (1679-1745). Lady Grange was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754), out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. News of her plight began to be known when letters were smuggled off St Kilda in 1738, taking two years to reach Lord Advocate Charles Erskine in Edinburgh in 1740. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745. The collection also includes other letters and papers related to Lady Grange, such as a letter of separation from Lady Grange to Lord Grange, transcriptions of Lady Grange's letters, and an article written by David Laing on the letters.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, Selection of letters
metadata.label: Repro Title

metadata.value: The image depicts a raid on a heronry by a group of falconers, a typical sport of the 17th century nobility. A knight and lady ride pillion fashion on the right, while two men dressed in holiday attire gesture to the sky, having just released their birds. To the left, a sportsman holding a long wand and hawk surveys the scene.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: A Solemn League and Covenant for Reformation, 1648
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: This is a signed copy of one of the most important documents of 17th century Scottish history  the agreement between the Scottish Covenanters and the English Parliamentarians which helped to ensure the defeat of the Royalists in the 1640s.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This volume of the Gospels was written in Germany in the 11th century for the Abbey of St. Matthias, Trier. Each Gospel has a fine illuminated title page. From 1015-92 the Benedictine Abbey of St Matthias was known as the monastery of St. Eucharius and the inscription on its books prior to 1150 read "Codex Sancti Eucharii," while those inscribed between 1150-1250 read, as this volume does, "Codex Sancti Eucharii santique Matthiae Apostoli."
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Four Gospels. This manuscript has a 13th century inscription which is thought to be from the monastery of St. Eucharius. Each gospel has an illuminated title and illuminated page of text.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: 'Account of the voyage and journal of the Scots African and Indian Fleet from yr setting firth from Kirkaldy bay upon 8th July 1698 to yr arrival at the port or bay of Darien upon the i of November yrafter 1699'
